snippet.textDisplay:
The thing about fleets is that once on the internet, always on the internet.. you can’t rely on people to not to take screenshots, or whatever.

Rienks case is interesting.. and she speaks many facts. Especially with the small channels thing. I will say that if you upload videos and private them, you probably should also keep them on your own pc rather than just uploading them to YouTube. You always want to back up your projects.. either way, YouTube’s handling of the situation overall was pretty bad..

Abortion case: it’s the woman’s choice, and the gov should be trying to support the women rather than than trying to make abortions unsafe

snippet.textDisplay:
) One month after the city of Wuhan was put on lockdown, the coronavirus infection cases and death tolls are still on the rise every day.

In Wuhan, a city home to 11 million people, the streets are still empty and the shops remain closed. All social activities have come to a halt. No one anticipates a quick end to the lockdown.

People are afraid of talking to each other, fearing becoming infected.

According to an internal document by the Hubei Communications Administration obtained by the Epoch Times, there are still about 25,000 people fleeing Wuhan every day, despite the strict travel ban, as indicated by the local residents’ cellphone geolocations.

But those who managed to escape are often met with hostility in other provinces. Some were reported and then arrested. Some were forcibly sent to hospitals, even if they weren’t showing any symptoms or confirmed to have the virus.

According to a video circulating online, one Wuhan resident who escaped to neighboring Hunan province was arrested. The local resident who reported him said, “It’s not that I didn’t want to be nice to you, but you came from Wuhan and I’m afraid of death.”

The coronavirus outbreak has brought out the worst in some people.

According to an article titled “Chinese city accused of stealing virus masks from hard-hit neighbour” by Reuters on February 6, the city of Dali in Yunnan Province intercepted hundreds of boxes of surgical masks bound for Chongqing.

Similar incidents were also reported in Dalian and Shenyang, Liaoning Province and Qingdao, Shandong Province.

From “Controllable and Preventable” to Complete Lockdown
On January 19, Li Gang, director and chief physician for the Wuhan Center for Disease Control and Prevention, said during a press conference that the epidemic was “preventable and controllable.”

Four days later, the authorities in Wuhan suddenly announced the lockdown of the city. All public transportation, including buses, subways, trains, ferries, and flights, was suspended.

Days later, more cities in Hubei Province, including Ezhou, Huanggang, Chibi, Xiantao, Zhijiang, Qianjjiang, Xianning, Jingmen, Dangyang, Huangshi, Enshi, and Xiaogan, were also put on lockdown.
snippet.textOriginal:
) One month after the city of Wuhan was put on lockdown, the coronavirus infection cases and death tolls are still on the rise every day.

In Wuhan, a city home to 11 million people, the streets are still empty and the shops remain closed. All social activities have come to a halt. No one anticipates a quick end to the lockdown. 

People are afraid of talking to each other, fearing becoming infected.

According to an internal document by the Hubei Communications Administration obtained by the Epoch Times, there are still about 25,000 people fleeing Wuhan every day, despite the strict travel ban, as indicated by the local residents’ cellphone geolocations.

But those who managed to escape are often met with hostility in other provinces. Some were reported and then arrested. Some were forcibly sent to hospitals, even if they weren’t showing any symptoms or confirmed to have the virus.

According to a video circulating online, one Wuhan resident who escaped to neighboring Hunan province was arrested. The local resident who reported him said, “It’s not that I didn’t want to be nice to you, but you came from Wuhan and I’m afraid of death.”

The coronavirus outbreak has brought out the worst in some people.

According to an article titled “Chinese city accused of stealing virus masks from hard-hit neighbour” by Reuters on February 6, the city of Dali in Yunnan Province intercepted hundreds of boxes of surgical masks bound for Chongqing. 

Similar incidents were also reported in Dalian and Shenyang, Liaoning Province and Qingdao, Shandong Province.

From “Controllable and Preventable” to Complete Lockdown
On January 19, Li Gang, director and chief physician for the Wuhan Center for Disease Control and Prevention, said during a press conference that the epidemic was “preventable and controllable.”

Four days later, the authorities in Wuhan suddenly announced the lockdown of the city. All public transportation, including buses, subways, trains, ferries, and flights, was suspended.

Days later, more cities in Hubei Province, including Ezhou, Huanggang, Chibi, Xiantao, Zhijiang, Qianjjiang, Xianning, Jingmen, Dangyang, Huangshi, Enshi, and Xiaogan, were also put on lockdown.

snippet.textDisplay:
With the whole abortion this I'm torn because who am I to tell someone what to do with their life but at the same time I do feel like we shouldn't be snuffing out a life just because so I say we go with 3 strikes rule.


1st- You pay nothing for it but your name is added to a list that you have had a abortion because accidents do happen and that can range from ops condom broke to something much more serious.


2nd- You pay double the cost of what a normal abortion would be and they are still keeping track of your records.


3rd- It's normal cost but now you are put on a list where it would be illegal for you to have a abortion after this time and if you ever did you would serve jail time because if you're going in for a 4th abortion you are just living reckless and need to be put in check.


That's my thoughts

snippet.textDisplay: Years ago before abortion was legal in many places , women would go to doctors or people who aren’t doctors that have no credentials at all, and get abortions in their home or the home of the person doing it. It would end in death of the women, or such serious complications that they can never have children again or have serious health problems. If they take it away , people will find a way to do it but it’s going to be extremely dangerous and risk the health of everyone involved. I understand people for it (I’m pro choice ) but I also understand people who don’t support it , but whether you support it or not everyone should be able to admit that it’s really dangerous taking that choice away knowing people will find other ways to do it.
snippet.textOriginal: Years ago before abortion was legal in many places , women would go to doctors or people who aren’t doctors that have no credentials at all, and get abortions in their home or the home of the person doing it. It would end in death of the women, or such serious complications that they can never have children again or have serious health problems. If they take it away , people will find a way to do it but it’s going to be extremely dangerous and risk the health of everyone involved. I understand people for it (I’m pro choice ) but I also understand people who don’t support it , but whether you support it or not everyone should be able to admit that it’s really dangerous taking that choice away knowing people will find other ways to do it.

snippet.textDisplay: Honestly I feel for Meghan Rienks. After a year and a half of uploading content to our channel every week and doing everything that is advised out there to grow, NOTHING has worked... Anyone interested in game reviews, check out our channel. Youtube certainly won't recommend it. Every episode gets a copyright claim, all claims always get resolved in favor of our channel, but it still happens. Not sure if we should keep doing this on YouTube if no one is recommended to watch even when we obey all the rules.

snippet.textDisplay: The whole hacking story annoys me because it ALL could have been avoided by simply turning two step authentication on their google accounts. Its available on ALL google accounts so there is no excuse. The two step auth system has NEVER been compromised. If you think its too inconvenient to have to enter a second code on top of your password then you forfeit the ability to complain when your account gets hacked.
snippet.textOriginal: The whole hacking story annoys me because it ALL could have been avoided by simply turning two step authentication on their google accounts. Its available on ALL google accounts so there is no excuse. The two step auth system has NEVER been compromised. If you think its too inconvenient to have to enter a second code on top of your password then you forfeit the ability to complain when your account gets hacked.

snippet.textDisplay: Re the hacked account: This sort of hacking has been happening a LOT. The account hijackers target people with decent follower bases, but not big name youtubers. An AMV channel i follow had their account hacked and had very similar uploads to this person. He had no way to get his account back so he just had his followers flag the account till it was deleted. Youtube needs to figure out a way to stop these account hijackers cause its getting bad.
snippet.textOriginal: Re the hacked account: This sort of hacking has been happening a LOT. The account hijackers target people with decent follower bases, but not big name youtubers. An AMV channel i follow had their account hacked and had very similar uploads to this person. He had no way to get his account back so he just had his followers flag the account till it was deleted. Youtube needs to figure out a way to stop these account hijackers cause its getting bad.

snippet.textDisplay: Personally i think that things for the creators on YouTube aren't gonna get any better unless there is a unified creator push back onto YouTube via some sort of YouTube union. what yt is essentially doing is violating labour laws, at least in the UK. So some kind of unified creator base would be a great resource that small creators and big creators could use to effectively hold YouTube to ransom. a YouTube wide strike whilst mostly impossible for most creators who make their livelihood on the platform, the big creators could certainly make a statement and gather the worlds attention. for me, this should go much further though, we should strike on all social media platforms until they give us rightful compensation for profiteering on our online data as an asset.
snippet.textOriginal: Personally i think that things for the creators on YouTube aren't gonna get any better unless there is a unified creator push back onto YouTube via some sort of YouTube union. what yt is essentially doing is violating labour laws, at least in the UK. So some kind of unified creator base would be a great resource that small creators and big creators could use to effectively hold YouTube to ransom. a YouTube wide strike whilst mostly impossible for most creators who make their livelihood on the platform, the big creators could certainly make a statement and gather the worlds attention. for me, this should go much further though, we should strike on all social media platforms until they give us rightful compensation for profiteering on our online data as an asset.

snippet.textDisplay: i actually have a friend that was running a pretty successful youtube channel a short while back, his channel suffered the same fate as meg's second where it got hacked and taken over, all his videos removed and some musical artist out east uploading his own stuff. he ended up making a new channel detailing what happened, but sadly, i think he gave up as he hasnt uploaded since the situation

snippet.textDisplay:
Just when I thought I was super safe here in the Philippines, (we had 3 Covid-19 cases, all tourists from Wuhan) now 2 new cases have been confirmed: a Japanese man who tested positive when he came home from here, and a Filipino senior citizen who has no travel history outside the country. 3 others, tourists, have turned up positive when they visited here. (Although their respective countries already had Covid-19 outbreaks, and one of them went to four different countries all with Covid-19 outbreaks.)

Dammit, I'm back to panicking in the corner of my mind.😟
snippet.textOriginal:
Just when I thought I was super safe here in the Philippines, (we had 3 Covid-19 cases, all tourists from Wuhan) now 2 new cases have been confirmed: a Japanese man who tested positive when he came home from here, and a Filipino senior citizen who has no travel history outside the country. 3 others, tourists, have turned up positive when they visited here. (Although their respective countries already had Covid-19 outbreaks, and one of them went to four different countries all with Covid-19 outbreaks.)

Dammit, I'm back to panicking in the corner of my mind.😟

snippet.textDisplay: Hey Phil! Basically the same thing happened to Kennis Russell a while back. His channel was hijacked and YouTube was of little assistance, even down to calling him by the wrong name.. His channel of 50k subs eventually became rebranded and began uploading literally hundreds of weird cartoons, TV shows and movies before YouTube deleted the channel.. You should check his video about it.. I'd say this kind of thing happens waaaay more than content creators are aware of..
snippet.textOriginal: Hey Phil! Basically the same thing happened to Kennis Russell a while back.
